articles.content:
The first of 30 Bob Ross works were auctioned to help public TV. They broke records 
         By Rachel Treisman 
        
           Updated Friday, November 14, 2025 • 11:32 AM EST 
        
        
           Heard on  All Things Considered 
        
      

         The first of 30 Bob Ross paintings — many of them created live on the PBS series that made him a household name — have been auctioned off to support public television. Ross, with his distinctive afro, soothing voice and sunny outlook, empowered millions of viewers to make and appreciate art through his show  The Joy of Painting . More than 400 half-hour episodes aired on PBS (and eventually the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) from 1983 to 1994, the year before Ross died of cancer at age 52. Ross' impact lives on: His show still airs on PBS and streams on platforms like Hulu  and Twitch . It has  surged in popularity  in recent years, particularly as viewers searched for comfort during COVID-19 lockdowns. Certified instructors continue teaching his wet-on-wet oil painting  technique to the masses , and the  Smithsonian acquired  several of his works for its permanent collection in 2019. But his artwork rarely goes up for sale — until recently.  In October, the nonprofit syndicator American Public Television (APT) announced it would auction off 30 of Ross' paintings to raise money for public broadcasters hit by federal funding cuts. It pledged to direct 100% of its net sales proceeds to APT and PBS stations nationwide. Auction house Bonhams is calling it the  "largest single offering of Bob Ross original works ever brought to market." Ross has become synonymous with public broadcasting and some activists have  even invoked him  in their calls for restoring federal funding to it. "It's a medium that Bob just cherished," said Joan Kowalski, president of Bob Ross, Inc., in a phone call with NPR. "With the cuts, it's just a natural inclination to support public television." The first three paintings sold in Los Angeles  on Nov. 11 . for a record-shattering $662,000. Bonhams says the works attracted hundreds of registrations, more than twice the usual number for that type of sale. Each sold for more than its estimated worth, led by  Winter's Peace,  which fetched $318,000 to set a new Ross auction record.  "As anticipated, these paintings inspired spirited bidding, achieved impressive results and broke global auction records, continuing the momentum we've seen building in [Ross'] market," said Robin Starr, the general manager of Bonhams Skinner, the auction house's Massachusetts branch. "These successes provide a solid foundation as we look ahead to 2026 and prepare to present the next group of Bob Ross works." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       The next trio of paintings will be auctioned in Massachusetts in late January. The rest will be sold throughout 2026 at Bonham's salerooms in Los Angeles, New York and Boston. How the offering could benefit public broadcasters  At President Trump's direction, Congress voted in July to  claw back $1.1 billion  in previously allocated funding for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB), leaving the country's roughly 330 PBS and 244 NPR stations in a precarious position. CPB began  shutting down  at the end of September, PBS has  already cut 15%  of its jobs, and several local TV and  radio stations  have also announced layoffs and closures. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "I think he would be very disappointed" about the CPB cuts, Kowalski said of Ross. "I think he would have decided to do exactly what we're doing right now ... I think this would have probably been his idea." Kowalski, whose parents founded Bob Ross Inc. together with the painter in 1985, said Ross favored positive activism over destructive or empty rhetoric. "That just was his nature," she said. "He was like that in real life. So I think this would have been exactly the thing that he would have chosen. I suddenly got really emotional thinking about that." The Ross auction aims to help stations pay their licensing fees to the  national TV channel Create , which in turn allows them to air popular public television programs including  The Best of the Joy of Painting  (based on Ross' show),  America's Test Kitchen, Rick Steve's Europe and  Julia Child's  French Chef Classics . Bonhams says the auction proceeds will help stations — particularly smaller and rural ones — defray the cost burden of licensing fees, making Create available to more of them. "This enables stations to maintain their educational programming while redirecting funds toward other critical operations and local content production threatened by federal funding cuts," the auction house says. Ross' paintings rarely hit the market The 30 paintings going up for sale span Ross' career and are all "previously unseen by the public except during their creation in individual episodes" of  The Joy of Painting,  according to Bonhams. Many have remained in secure storage ever since. They include vibrant landscapes, with the serene mountains, lake views and "happy trees" that became his trademark. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Ross started painting during his 20-year career in the Air Force, much of which was spent in Alaska. That experience shaped his penchant for landscapes and ability to work quickly — and,  he later said , his desire not to raise his voice once out of the service. Once on the airwaves, Ross' soft-spoken guidance and gentle demeanor won over millions of viewers. His advice applied to art as well as life: Mistakes are just "happy accidents," talent is a "pursued interest," and it's important to "take a step back and look." "Ross' gentle teaching style and positive philosophy made him a cultural icon whose influence extends far beyond the art world," Bonhams says. While Ross was prolific, his paintings were intended for teaching instead of selling, and therefore rarely go on the market. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In August, Bonhams sold two of Ross' early 1990s mountain and lake scenes as part of an online auction of American art. They fetched $114,800 and $95,750, surpassing expectations and setting a new auction world record for Ross at the time. Kowalski says that's when her gears started turning.  "And it just got me to thinking, that's a substantial amount of money," she recalled. "And what if, what if, what if?"  Bonhams officially estimates that the 30 paintings could go for a combined total between $850,000 and $1.4 million. But Starr, of the auction house, predicted in October that they will continue to exceed expectations, based on their artistic value, nostalgia factor and more.  "Now we add in the fact that these are selling to benefit public television, I think the bidding is going to be very happy," she said. "Happy trees, happy bidding."  Disclosure: This story was edited by general assignment editor Carol Ritchie and managing editor Vickie Walton-James. Under NPR's protocol for reporting on itself, no NPR corporate official or news executive reviewed this story before it was posted publicly. 
         
         Transcript 
         SCOTT DETROW, HOST:   Public broadcasting helped make artist Bob Ross a household name. Now the late painter's company wants to give back. It is auctioning off dozens of his original works - many of them painted live on a show - to support public TV after federal funding cuts. NPR's Rachel Treisman reports. RACHEL TREISMAN, BYLINE: Bob Ross brought his soothing voice, sunny outlook and trademark afro to over 400 episodes of "The Joy Of Painting," which aired on PBS between 1983 and his death in 1995. (SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "THE JOY OF PAINTING") BOB ROSS: We don't make mistakes, you know. We have happy accidents. TREISMAN: Decades later, viewers are streaming it online and still watching it on public TV. It's a medium that Ross cherished, says Joan Kowalski, the president of Bob Ross, Inc. JOAN KOWALSKI: He used to talk about that a lot. He felt like he was in someone's living room and it was just that one person. TREISMAN: At the direction of President Trump, Congress voted in July to claw back over $1 billion for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, slashing funding for PBS and NPR stations across the country. The next month, the auction house Bonhams sold two Bob Ross paintings for over $200,000 combined, exceeding their estimated value to set a new record. KOWALSKI: And it just got me to thinking, you know, that's a substantial amount of money, and what if? What if? What if? TREISMAN: Kowalski, along with Bonhams and American Public Television, came up with a plan. They will auction off 30 of Ross' original paintings, with all net proceeds going to APT and PBS stations nationwide. They hope the money raised will help stations pay the licensing fees to air popular programs like "America's Test Kitchen," "Rick Steves' Europe" and "The Best Of The Joy Of Painting." Kowalski says if Ross were alive today... KOWALSKI: I think this would've probably been his idea. TREISMAN: It's rare for Ross' paintings to make it out of storage and onto the market. He painted most of these 30 works on TV, while some are from his instructional books. They won't all be sold at once. The first three paintings are going up for auction in Los Angeles in November. Here's Robin Starr, the general manager of the auction house's Massachusetts branch. ROBIN STARR: Throughout the next year or so, we will be metering out the other 27 works, and those will be coming up out of our California, New York and Massachusetts galleries. TREISMAN: Many are Ross' trademark landscapes, with vibrant mountains, lake views, lush forests, and his signature happy little trees. Here he is working on "Home In The Valley," a 1993 painting that will be up for auction in November. (SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "THE JOY OF PAINTING") ROSS: It's very simple, and it will teach you how to use all the equipment. And it's a lot of fun. TREISMAN: The auction house estimates the paintings could bring in up to $1.4 million, but organizers are hoping they will once again exceed expectations. As Starr said, happy trees, happy bidding. (SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "THE JOY OF PAINTING") ROSS: And with the old signature on here, I think we're going to call that one finished. TREISMAN: Rachel Treisman, NPR News. (SOUNDBITE OF NATHANIEL DREW X TOM FOX'S "REVERIE")

articles.title: The Trump Administration Plans Major Shift Away from Long-Term Housing for Homelessness
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration is implementing a major overhaul of federal homelessness policy, shifting funding from long-term, permanent 'Housing First' programs to transitional housing that requires participants to engage in work and addiction treatment. While overall funding increases from $3.6 billion to $3.9 billion, critics warn that the abrupt change—delayed by a federal shutdown and marked by a lack of advance notice—could leave 170,000 people without stable housing. The policy, initiated by an executive order signed in July 2025, also removes automatic renewals of existing housing programs, risks creating months-long funding gaps, and increases funding for faith-based groups. Critics argue this shift undermines trauma-informed care, disproportionately impacts vulnerable populations like seniors and disabled individuals, and fails to address the primary root cause of homelessness: rising rent prices. Supporters, including conservative experts like Stephen Eide, believe transitional housing better addresses addiction and recovery needs, but concerns remain about its practical and ethical implications for those who have found stability through permanent housing.
keyTakeAways: The Trump administration is shifting federal homelessness funding away from long-term, permanent housing (Housing First model) toward transitional housing that requires work and addiction treatment.

Overall homelessness funding is increasing from $3.6 billion to $3.9 billion, but this does not offset the risk of 170,000 people losing housing due to the sudden and abrupt nature of the policy change.
HUD will no longer automatically renew existing long-term housing programs, potentially displacing formerly homeless individuals who have lived in subsidized housing for years.
The new policy may leave critical gaps in funding, with months-long periods between current and new funding cycles, endangering stability for vulnerable individuals.

The shift reflects a conservative backlash against the bipartisan 'Housing First' model, which prioritized permanent housing and treatment, and instead supports transitional housing with sobriety mandates.

Critics, including homelessness advocates and experts, argue that this approach undermines trauma-informed care, increases the risk of homelessness, and fails to address the root cause of rent-driven homelessness.
The policy may disproportionately impact seniors and disabled individuals who rely on stable, long-term housing programs.
Faith-based groups are expected to receive more funding under the new policy, signaling a shift toward religiously affiliated services in homelessness response.

Experts like Stephen Eide of the Manhattan Institute argue that transitional housing better addresses addiction and recovery needs, while critics like Stephanie Klasky-Gamer warn it may exclude people unable to meet sobriety or treatment prerequisites.

articles.content:
The Trump administration plans major shift away from long-term housing for homelessness 
         By Jennifer Ludden 
        
           Updated Friday, November 14, 2025 • 12:58 PM EST 
        
        
      

         The Trump administration is upending its homelessness policy, with deep cuts to funding for long-term housing. Instead, it will shift money toward transitional housing that requires work and addiction treatment. In a statement, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said  the new policies  will "restore accountability" and promote "self-sufficiency" by addressing the "root causes of homelessness, including illicit drugs and mental illness." It also noted that overall homelessness funding is going up, from $3.6 billion to $3.9 billion. 170,000 people could be at risk of losing their housing  Critics warn the major overhaul could put 170,000 people at risk of losing their housing again. And they say the timing is terrible. Normally, funding notices go out months earlier, but now programs around the country will have little time to start applying for new funding. And in many places, it will leave a months-long gap after current funding runs out and before new money flows. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "We'll move very, very fast," said HUD policy expert Robert Marbut, in response to such concerns. He also noted the federal shutdown delayed the funding notice, though homelessness advocates say it was already behind schedule before that. In another change, HUD will no longer automatically renew existing programs – creating the possibility that formerly homeless people who've lived in subsidized housing for years will be forced out. In fact, Marbut said the agency expects some programs to no longer receive funding because it will go to others instead. The agency also says it's opening up more funding for faith-based groups. The National Alliance to End Homelessness says the new policies could upend life for people who've found stability in permanent housing programs, many of them seniors or disabled. "HUD's new funding priorities slam the door on them, their providers, and their communities. Make no mistake: homelessness will only increase because of this reckless and irresponsible decision," CEO Ann Oliva said in a statement. The new policies could also shift more funding to places that enforce bans on homeless encampments. "Donald Trump's approach to homelessness does nothing to address the sky-high cost of rent, which remains the main cause of homelessness," Jesse Rabinowitz of the National Homelessness Law Center said in a statement. The funding shift reflects a conservative backlash to longstanding policies For two decades, federal funding has prioritized getting people into permanent housing and then offering them treatment. That policy is called Housing First and has long had bipartisan support. Backers say the approach has a proven track record of keeping people off the streets. But critics counter that it has failed to stem the steady rise of homelessness to what are now historic levels. Those critics include President Trump, who has long pushed cities to clear homeless encampments from streets and parks. The new funding shift reflects an  executive order he signed in July , which also sought to make it easier to confine unhoused people in mental institutions against their will. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Marbut, the HUD policy expert, also said Housing First policies have failed to address rising death rates among unhoused people from meth and fentanyl addiction. "The influence of Housing First just became too powerful," says Stephen Eide, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a conservative think-tank. He calls it a top-down approach, and says for years it was hard to get funding unless a program followed that policy. Eide says that left out a large group of people who may not need permanent housing or who may want the enforced sobriety it does not offer. "I think what we're going to be looking for is a reinvestment in transitional housing," he says. That means places people can stay for 18 months or so to get sober, or recover in other ways, and then — ideally — move out and succeed on their own. There's broad agreement that the U.S. needs more of every kind of support for homeless people: permanent housing, rehab and mental illness treatment. But critics of HUD's shift fear this may make it harder for some to get help. "It is moving away from trauma-informed care, and that's problematic," says Stephanie Klasky-Gamer, president and CEO of LA Family Housing in Los Angeles. For example, she thinks this will lead more shelters to bar people unless they're already sober or enrolled in recovery or mental health care. But that's a high bar for many people, she says, and it could backfire.

articles.title: Comey and James seek case dismissal, arguing prosecutor was illegally appointed
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Former FBI Director James Comey and New York Attorney General Letitia James are seeking dismissal of their indictments, arguing that the interim U.S. attorney Lindsey Halligan was illegally appointed by Attorney General Pam Bondi, bypassing Senate confirmation and judicial oversight. Halligan, a White House aide with no prosecutorial experience, replaced Erik Siebert, who resigned under pressure after Trump criticized the lack of action against political opponents. Defense lawyers claim this appointment violates statutory law and undermines prosecutorial independence, while the Justice Department asserts the indictment was valid and based on grand jury findings. The cases are seen as politically charged, stemming from the long-standing conflict between Trump and Comey, and the legal challenges also include claims of vindictiveness and presidential animus. A U.S. District Judge, Cameron McGowan Currie, is expected to issue a decision by Thanksgiving, which could determine whether the prosecutions proceed or are dismissed permanently.
keyTakeAways: Lindsey Halligan's appointment as interim U.S. attorney was criticized as potentially illegal, as it bypassed the constitutional and statutory requirement for Senate confirmation and federal judicial oversight after the 120-day interim period ended.

Defense lawyers argue that Halligan's lack of prosecutorial experience and the absence of Senate confirmation make her appointment unlawful and that the indictments against James Comey and Letitia James are invalid due to this procedural flaw.
The cases are politically charged, stemming from the historical conflict between Trump and Comey, and the ongoing animus toward James, particularly after her financial fraud verdict against Trump.

The Justice Department defends Halligan's appointment as lawful, citing no explicit prohibition in the law and asserting that the grand jury followed its oath and facts, regardless of appointment procedures.

A missing section in the grand jury proceedings has raised concerns about transparency and integrity, with the Justice Department later clarifying it was not a transcription error but a deliberate exclusion of deliberation time.
Both Comey and James have pleaded not guilty, and their legal team is pursuing multiple challenges, including claims of vindictiveness and political motivation in the prosecutions.

articles.content:
Comey and James seek case dismissal, arguing prosecutor was illegally appointed 
         By The Associated Press 
        
           Friday, November 14, 2025 • 1:42 AM EST 
        
        
      

         ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Lawyers for former FBI Director James Comey and New York Attorney General Letitia James asked a judge Thursday to dismiss the cases against them, saying the prosecutor who secured the indictments was illegally installed in the role. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       U.S. District Judge Cameron McGowan Currie said she expects to decide by Thanksgiving on challenges to Lindsey Halligan's appointment as interim U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia. That decision could help determine the fate of the politically charged cases, which were both shepherded by the hastily installed Halligan and together have amplified concerns that the Justice Department is being used as a weapon to target President Donald Trump's perceived adversaries. Halligan was installed in the job at Trump's urging by Attorney General Pam Bondi in September, just days before Comey was indicted, in what defense lawyers say was an end-run around the constitutional and statutory rules governing the appointment of U.S. attorneys. They say the maneuver was designed to ensure indictments against the president's political opponents after the prosecutor who had been overseeing the two investigations, but had not brought charges, was effectively forced out. "Ms. Halligan was the sole prosecutor in the grand jury room, and when the sole prosecutor lacks the authority," said Ephraim McDowell, one of Comey's defense lawyers, "that's not going to be a harmless error." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       U.S. attorneys, top federal prosecutors who oversee regional Justice Department outposts across the country, are typically nominated by the president and then confirmed by the Senate. Attorneys general do have the authority to name an interim U.S. attorney who can serve for 120 days, but lawyers for Comey and James argued that once that period expires, the law gives federal judges the exclusive say of who gets to fill the vacancy. The interim US attorney resigned under pressure After then-interim U.S. attorney Erik Siebert resigned in September while facing Trump administration pressure to bring charges against Comey and James, Bondi installed Halligan, a White House aide with no prior prosecutorial experience. The appointment followed a Trump post on Truth Social in which he complained to Bondi about the lack of prosecutorial action against his political enemies and said, "JUSTICE MUST BE SERVED, NOW!!!" Siebert had been appointed by Bondi in January to serve as interim U.S. attorney. Trump in May announced his intention to nominate him, and judges in the Eastern District unanimously agreed after his 120-day period expired that he should be retained in the role. But after the Trump administration effectively pushed him out in September, the Justice Department again opted to make an interim appointment in place of the courts, something defense lawyers say it was not empowered under the law to do. "If the government were to prevail here," McDowell said, then it "would never need to go through Senate confirmation again for U.S. attorneys." He said any dismissal of the indictment must be permanent, with no opportunity to bring the case again, to avoid rewarding the government for a violation. The Justice Department defends Halligan's appointment The Justice Department maintains that the law does not explicitly prohibit successive appointments of interim U.S. attorneys by the attorney general. Henry Whitaker, a lawyer for the department, argued that the indictment was properly returned by a grand jury and should not be dismissed over what he described as at most a paperwork or clerical error. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "The grand jury made a decision based on the facts and the law, and they followed their oath," Whitaker said. He also said that even if there were questions about Halligan's appointment, they were resolved by the fact that Bondi had personally ratified the indictment and reviewed the grand jury proceedings. But Currie, the judge, questioned whether that was possible given that a section of the grand jury proceedings that were produced to her was, for unexplained reasons, missing a section. A Justice Department spokesperson later said that there was no missing time and that the time period in question concerns when the grand jury was deliberating, which "would not be included in a transcription." Comey has pleaded not guilty to charges of making a false statement and obstructing Congress, and James, a Democrat, has pleaded not guilty to mortgage fraud allegations. The challenges to Halligan's appointment are part of a multiprong effort to get the prosecutions tossed before trial. Their lawyers have separately argued that the prosecutions are improperly vindictive and motivated by the president's personal animus toward their clients and should therefore be dismissed. Trump's history with Comey and James Comey, as FBI director in the early months of Trump's first term, infuriated the president through his oversight of an investigation into potential ties between Russia and Trump's 2016 campaign. Trump fired Comey in May 2017. The two have been open adversaries since, with Comey labeling Trump "unethical" and comparing him to a Mafia boss and Trump branding Comey an "untruthful slime ball" and calling for him to be punished because of the Russia investigation. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       James has been a frequent target of Trump's ire, especially since she won a staggering judgment against him and the Trump Organization in a lawsuit alleging he defrauded banks by overstating the value of his real estate holdings on financial statements. An appeals court overturned the fine, which had ballooned to more than $500 million with interest, but upheld a lower court's finding that Trump had committed fraud.

articles.content:
How 'Fascism' became a meme 
         By Brittany Luse, Alexis Williams, Barton Girdwood, Neena Pathak, Mika Ellison  
        
           Monday, November 10, 2025 • 3:00 AM EST 
        
        
      

         It's hard to spend time online without encountering someone calling President Trump a fascist. Trump himself has used the word against his own opponents. Others have used the word to denounce Skinny-Tok as "body fascism." But why are Americans so willing to use the word? And is its ubiquity making it lose its meaning? In this episode, Brittany is joined by Nicholas Ensley Mitchell, a professor of education and policy at the University of Kansas. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Episode Highlights Why "fascism" has become a go-to term LUSE: What are people trying to point out when they return to the term "fascism"? What are they really trying to say? MITCHELL: Danger. Fascism as a meme is closely synonymous with danger. [It communicates that] there is a threat and it's an active threat. Whenever you call someone a fascist, you call a group a fascist, you are not just saying that, "Oh, they just exist." No. These guys are trying to take something away from you. They are trying to repress you. So it's a recognition that there is danger, and it's coming after me. It's an ingrained alarm in American culture. And I think despite all the changes in how it's been used in American history, it retains that sense of urgency. That this is not something to sleep on. The keys to fighting fascism could be in American history MITCHELL: When you think of Jim Crow as fascism, then that makes Black history and the resistance to Jim Crow an example of how you fight fascism. We have this image of the Civil Rights Movement: the bus boycotts, Rosa Parks is tired so she won't give up her seat, Martin Luther King gives a speech where he just talks about the content of character. What it actually was, in many regards, and how segregationists saw it, was a revolt. Black people have been calling — I mean, we've been talking about fascism [since] the thirties. Langston Hughes, he says in 1937, "We Negroes in America do not have to be told what fascism is [in action]. We know." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Is "fascism" the right term for our current moment?   LUSE:  [Responding to Mitchell saying "cultural upheaval" more aptly describes our current moment]  I mean, when you say "cultural upheaval," that phrase is so neutral. I think that makes sense. But I will say, that when you say that to me, I understand why some people, regardless of where they are in the political spectrum, would reach for fascism because "social upheaval" doesn't satisfy the feeling of fear and discomfort that I think many people feel when these big moments of change are happening. MITCHELL: I would agree. And I think that's why you see this term get used so much. I think being afraid and being anxious, that is a normal reaction. That is not people overreacting. Because [cultural upheaval] is the environment into which European fascism emerged. But also, it's the environment that the civil rights movement really worked its power to force America to be a democracy. That is the outcome of the civil rights movement. I use the term cultural upheaval because these are tectonic shifts happening in the culture. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       
         
         Transcript 
         BRITTANY LUSE, HOST:   Over the past few weeks, we've been breaking down the history, subtext and evolving meanings of the buzzwords you hear all over the news and social media. This is the ABCs of the culture wars. Our final word is F for fascism. NICHOLAS ENSLEY MITCHELL: We don't have a lot of terms in American society that are kind of cross-political, cross-cultural. Fascism is one them. LUSE: That's Professor Nicholas Ensley Mitchell. He teaches education theory, policy and practice at the University of Kansas. And he's right. You hear this word all over the political spectrum - from the press account of California Governor Gavin Newsom calling Homeland Security adviser Stephen Miller a fascist in all caps on X, to then-presidential nominee Donald Trump calling former Vice President Kamala Harris a fascist. (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING) PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: She's a Marxist, communist, fascist. LUSE: So how do we make sense of the word fascist being thrown around like this? Well, Professor Mitchell has been writing about the history of the word, and he's offering a perspective that I haven't really heard in mainstream conversations about fascism. MITCHELL: So I think we can talk about this really as just a meme, in the sense that we talk about other memes on the internet. Fascism - it's a succinct way of talking about an oppressive cultural regime or government or, you know, even vibe. LUSE: Yeah. I mean, to your point, it's not just being used in a political context. Like, I've seen people accuse some influencers of, quote-unquote, "body fascism" when they talk about weight loss and body image. You know, it shows up in a lot of different parts of American discourse. MITCHELL: And the reason for that is really tied up in American history. I mean, going really back into the - to the Second World War, you know, which is this conflict that just defines America. LUSE: What Professor Mitchell means is that modern American identity was crystallized in opposition to fascism. I mean, if you grew up in the American school system, I'm sure you can see the image right now of American soldiers heroically going to Europe to fight the Nazis in World War II. (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING) FRANKLIN D ROOSEVELT: Never before has there been a greater challenge to life, liberty and civilization. LUSE: They were fighting against fascism, against an ideology seen as counter to the American ideals of freedom and democracy. (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING) ROOSEVELT: We believe that the Nazis and the fascists have asked for it, and they're going to get it. MITCHELL: Fascism is explicitly authoritarian. It is chauvinistic. It is sexist, and it is ultra nationalistic and racist. It's very obsessed with us and them. It's not just government. It's a full cultural movement. It is obsessed with aesthetics, how people dress, how people talk, symbols on buildings, the layout of cities, you know, ghettos versus where everybody else could go. LUSE: Other scholars define fascism as a dictatorship with enthusiastic public support and say that fascism can develop in a democracy when the people start to feel their leader doesn't have enough power to avert a perceived national crisis. And, you know, these definitions might stir a feeling in you right now. But there's an important difference between feeling that something is fascist and a formal system of fascism. MITCHELL: You know, in a democratic pluralistic society, you know, meaning is determined by individuals. You know, we determine meaning for ourselves. In a fascist society, meaning is determined by the state. They tell you what the history means. They tell you what everything means. LUSE: And in Professor Mitchell's essay, titled "Want To Learn How To Respond To Fascism? Study Black History," he lays out why he thinks American history showcases this country's much older relationship with fascism, long before Nazism and World War II. MITCHELL: Fascists are always concerned with, like, let's have this mythic past so then we can control who we are and say who belongs and who doesn't belong and whose grievances and histories are real and who's are just complaining. In my experience, they all try to go for a very sanitized history, rather than what I call the messy truth. LUSE: Today, we're getting into why Professor Mitchell thinks this country needs to deal with what he calls its own fascist past. MITCHELL: And that's the messy truth of American history. It's a lot of contradictions. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: Hello, hello. I'm Brittany Luse, and you're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR, a show about what's going on in culture and why it doesn't happen by accident. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: You know, we're going to get into the exact polling in a second, but a big headline from the past year is that a majority of Americans - particularly Democratic voters - have said that they see Trump as a fascist or dictator-like. I mean, if you did a quick search right now, you can find think piece on think piece arguing, you know, whether the country is sliding into fascism. I know a lot of people have concerns about our current moment, but is fascism the right descriptor for it? MITCHELL: Oh, that's a huge question. LUSE: (Laughter) Sorry. Sorry to lay that on you. MITCHELL: Oh, well, I mean, it is not surprising to me that people use that term because this term has been used various ways. I mean, of course, Nixon was called a fascist. Reagan was called a fascist. Obama was called a fascist... LUSE: Yeah. MITCHELL: ...For the Affordable Care Act. But also during the war - you know, in the war on terror, the term Islamic fascism was so common. LUSE: Right, right. MITCHELL: And that happens exactly when social media is starting to take off. That's early Facebook, later early Twitter - or X now. LUSE: Well, to kind of think in terms of today, a widely talked about poll from October 2024 taken right before the presidential election found that 49% of Americans identified Trump as a fascist. To your point about this being a political meme, 22% also described Vice President Harris as a fascist. Now, in April of this year, in another poll, 41% of Americans strongly defined Trump as a, quote, "dangerous dictator," compared with 27% who strongly defined him as a, quote, "strong leader who should be given power to restore America's greatness." What do these snapshots say about the state of this country? MITCHELL: For the past 25 years, we have been in this really intense cultural battle over who are we and who do we want to be? And we've had so much dynamic change in the past 25 years from, you know, Bush, 9/11 war on terror. And then you get the first Black president. And then, you know, Trump, from completely outside of the political world, he comes in, and then that brings his own - its own sort of upheaval. Me, personally, I think that when historians look back on this era, we're going to look at kind of like the twin - like, the twin poles of the change of whatever comes after this, it's going to be Obama and Trump. LUSE: Yeah. MITCHELL: Like... LUSE: And they also represent - they - even just in the popular imagination, they represent, in some ways, things that can feel very polar opposite to many people. MITCHELL: Yes. LUSE: And they are side by side. MITCHELL: And who gets to have power? And, you know... LUSE: Yeah. MITCHELL: ...Who, you know, that - you know, Obama, this, you know - and not just for him being, you know - him being African American. He's also not - he's an academic. He's very new to politics. And then you have Trump. Trump is a businessman, and he was a media figure, very kind of pop cultural figure. Of course, both of - you know, these aren't the first academic president and, you know, Trump's not the first... LUSE: Or the first, like, celebrity president, either, yeah. MITCHELL: So with all that change and all that clash, it does not surprise me that people were out there calling Obama a fascist, and it does not surprise me that people are calling Trump a fascist because that meme is our - it's our stand-in for there's a lot of change, and it's scaring some people. LUSE: So is kind of calling President Trump fascist, is this kind of - is this just like political name-calling or something adjacent to that, that may need some more teasing out? MITCHELL: I think it's the second one. We're grappling - I think Americans are grappling with how to make sense of a lot of this. So, like, there's one really key fact that I think is relevant to any discussion about Trump - and I don't know why more people don't talk about it. Every single one of Donald Trump's electoral coalitions was multiracial. It was multiclass. I was multi-ethnic. Multiracial fascism is not something that happens. LUSE: I mean, it - I know what you're saying is true. We have reported on these things... MITCHELL: Yes, you all have, yeah. LUSE: ...On this show before, but pulling just that fact out for a second and looking at it, it - I mean... MITCHELL: So... LUSE: It's like - it feels like you hit reset on my brain. MITCHELL: Trump didn't just have one multiracial coalition. He had three. LUSE: Yeah. MITCHELL: In the third election, he picks up a third of the non-white vote. You can't ignore that in any of these conversations, but a lot of people do. LUSE: Yeah. I guess maybe part of what you're saying then is that fascism doesn't quite fit as a descriptor because Trump has a diverse coalition backing him and that, you know, the idea of a multiracial coalition doesn't really fit with the definitions of fascism. And maybe there's a different word that might fit better. MITCHELL: So it's like, when you put it all together, what does this say about who we are - and into that uncertainty. LUSE: Yeah. MITCHELL: That's where you're going to see fascism get a lot of track in the popular culture as a meme for describing what they're seeing. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: Coming up - the words Professor Mitchell thinks define this moment. Stay with us. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: Thinking about fascism again and in the broader sense, not just in the way that people are maybe using it to describe a swift political change that feels wrong to them, many Americans think of fascism as something very un-American. Not just, like, against American values, but more specifically, something that has happened before in history, but never here. But you argue that America has a strong history of fascism in Jim Crow and in American segregation. Tell me more about that. MITCHELL: Sure. We have this interesting and very impoverished view of Jim Crow. We'll talk about it as oh, it was separate water fountains and separate schools. No, it was that, but it was also ghettoizing people. It was brutalizing them. It was state-sanctioned murder and terrorism. You know, you get, like, you know, events like Red Summer where you have nationwide race riots. And then, of course, you get probably, you know, the most famous of those being the Tulsa Race Massacre in 1921. If I put those sorts of things in a European context, we would call those pogroms. LUSE: Yeah, yeah. For those who don't know, pogroms were violent attacks or riots targeting Jewish people by both Russians and Germans in the 19th and early 20th century. MITCHELL: You know, so you have these parallels between what's happening with Jewish people and minorities in, you know, Nazi Germany and in Europe and what's happening in the United States. It's the sort of thing that inspires the Nazis. The Nazis are looking at American eugenics for inspiration for their own murderous eugenics programs. LUSE: And just to lay out our timeline here - the Jim Crow period in the United States was from 1877 to around the 1950s. Nazism and its eugenics program really took off in the 1930s, when Jim Crow laws were still in effect. MITCHELL: You know, there's a great book, "Hitler's American Model," that gets into how much the antisemitic laws were directly inspired by the Jim Crow laws, and they have the - one of the big justices, rather, of the Nazi regime saying in the book - and it's me paraphrasing - this set of laws is great for us. The only problem is that it considers Jewish people to be white. LUSE: I mean, I think, you know, some people might argue that Jim Crow isn't exactly quote-unquote, "fascism," but in your view, why do you think it's important to frame Jim Crow like this? MITCHELL: When you think of Jim Crow as fascism, then that makes Black history and the resistance to Jim Crow an example of how do you fight fascism. We have this image of the Civil Rights Movement that, you know, you get the bus boycotts, Rosa Parks is tired so she won't give up her seat. LUSE: Right. MITCHELL: Martin Luther King gives a speech where he just talks about the content of character... LUSE: Right. MITCHELL: ...Versus what it actually was in many regards, and honestly, how segregationists saw it, that it was a revolt. Black people have been calling - I mean, we have been talking about fascism in the '30s. You know, Langston Hughes, he says in 1937, we Negroes in America do not have to be told what fascism is. We know. LUSE: So even the conversation we are having right now is not new. This is (inaudible). MITCHELL: Yeah, it's about a hundred years old. I want to say - I mean, Du Bois linked Jim Crow and fascism and, like, imperialism. But I think the big takeaway for me when I was talking about understanding Jim Crow as a form of fascism and why is that important, it's because in America, we have this view of American democracy as these ancient pillars driven into the ground. But if you're going to be bluntly honest, can you call yourself a democracy if a bunch of your people can't vote because of the color of their skin? LUSE: It's a fair question. MITCHELL: Or because of their sex? So to me - and I agree with the scholars who, you know, argue this - that America doesn't become a liberal democracy until 1965... LUSE: When the Voting Rights Act is passed. MITCHELL: ...When the Voting Rights Act is passed. So then in that sense, American liberal democracy is very fragile. It's new. Black people and non-white people and also white people across the political spectrum who were, they're down with this - they're down with the Civil Rights Movement - so conservative, liberal, all of that, they joined this revolt to overthrow this system. It's a multiracial creation. It's a multi-ethnic creation. It's a multipolitical creation. Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives and progressives all had hands in creating this thing. LUSE: For people who are seeing the continued stripping of the Voting Rights Act, for people who are thinking about the fact that most Americans support legalized access to abortion, and now, that's something that's not guaranteed by our Constitution anymore. MITCHELL: Yeah. LUSE: Many people feel like their rights are being stripped away. And I understand where you're coming from, where you say multiracial fascism is not a thing. I'm not necessarily saying that that's the proper term, but I'm trying to think about people who are going to be listening who might think, OK, well, if that's not fascism, then what is? What's a better descriptor? What's a better way to name this? MITCHELL: Cultural upheaval. I think we are in a period of intense cultural upheaval where the entire social contract is being relitigated. LUSE: I mean, I'll say, when you say cultural upheaval, that phrase is so neutral (laughter). And I think that, like, that makes sense, but I will say that when you say that to me, I understand why some people - regardless of where they are on the political spectrum - would reach for fascism, because social upheaval, it doesn't satisfy. It doesn't satisfy the feeling of fear and discomfort that I think many people feel when these big moments of change are happening. MITCHELL: I would agree. And I think that's why you see this term get used so much. I think being afraid and being anxious, those are - that is a normal reaction. That is not people overreacting because that is the environment into which, you know, European fascism emerged. But also, you know, it's the environment that the Civil Rights Movement really worked its power to force America to be a democracy. That is the actual outcome of the Civil Rights Movement. You know, I use the term cultural upheaval because these are tectonic shifts happening, you know, in the culture. And really, the question is, what's going to happen? How are people going to react? Because the government does not have the ability to just renegotiate the social contract. The entire culture is going to do that. LUSE: I have one last question. I mean, you know, even in the absence of total, you know, consensus regarding the characterization of our current political moment, because there are lots of people who feel like the country is moving in the right direction, what are people trying to point out or say when they return to the term fascism? What are they really trying to say? MITCHELL: Danger. Fascism as a meme, it is closely synonymous with danger. There is a threat, and it's an active threat. Because whenever you call someone a fascist or you call a group a fascist, you are not just saying that as a simple category of, oh, they just exist. No, like, these guys are trying to take something away from you. They are trying to repress you. So it's a recognition of there is danger, and it's coming after me. It's a ingrained alarm in American culture. And, you know, I think, despite all the changes and how it's been used in American history, it retains that sense of urgency that this is not something to sleep on. LUSE: Well, Nicholas, I really appreciate you sharing your knowledge with me today. I really, really got so much out of this conversation. Thank you so much. MITCHELL: Thank you for having me. LUSE: That was Professor Nicholas Ensley Mitchell. He teaches education theory, policy and practice at the University of Kansas. And I'm going to put on my influencer hat for a second and ask you to please subscribe to this show on Spotify, Apple or wherever you're listening. Click follow so you know the latest in culture while it's still hot. This episode of IT'S BEEN A MINUTE was produced by... ALEXIS WILLIAMS, BYLINE: Alexis Williams. BARTON GIRDWOOD, BYLINE: Barton Girdwood. LUSE: This episode was edited by... NEENA PATHAK, BYLINE: Neena Pathak. LUSE: Our executive producer is... VERALYN WILLIAMS, BYLINE: Veralyn Williams. LUSE: Our VP of programming is... YOLANDA SANGWENI, BYLINE: Yolanda Sangweni. LUSE: All right. That's all for this episode of IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. I'm Brittany Luse. Talk soon.

articles.content:
Our relationship with money is emotional. How to make the most of your cash 
         By Andee Tagle 
        
           Updated Thursday, April 14, 2022 • 6:54 PM EDT 
        
        
      

         It doesn't take an expert to know that money is so much more than dollars and cents. Our relationship with money is  emotional.  Hopes and fears, guilt and shame — they can all play a significant role in your financial life.  And those feelings can be tied to lots of things: our upbringing, our environment, plus, y' know, all the money messaging in the world and the media. But honing those feelings and creating your own strong, secure financial voice? That takes some expertise.  Tiffany Aliche, better known as The Budgetnista, is a financial expert, educator, and author of the new book  Get Good With Money   (out March 30) .  Her book is a super practical guide to getting your financial house in order to achieve what Aliche calls financial wholeness. It's based around ten pillars: budgeting, savings, debt, credit, learning to earn, investing, insurance, net worth, getting your financial team in place and estate planning. Her book dives deep into each of these topics, but Aliche says this process begins with understanding your own financial identity and the many feelings and environmental forces that shape it.  " For me, money is more mindset than dollars and coins, "  she says. We can all, says Aliche, get good with money — we just have to get good with our feelings, first. Read on for tips for accessing your emotions around money, and learning to strengthen your financial voice. This interview has been condensed and edited for clarity.  Andee Tagle: You talk about how you used to live in the state of financial fear, and you say that financial wholeness is the cure to that financial fear, or to financial trauma. I love that idea. How do you define that term?  Tiffany Aliche:  I define financial wholeness as when all aspects of your financial life, and there's ten that we lean into truly — when all of these aspects of your financial life are working congruently for what I like to call your greatest good, your biggest benefit and your richest life. I would say financial freedom is for the few, but financial wholeness is for everyone. It doesn't matter how much you make. It doesn't matter what you do for a living. It doesn't matter how old you are. Financial wholeness can be achieved by everyone. And so it's just a holistic view of what to do with my money and how to maximize and make the most of it.  
       
      Related Story:  How Filing Taxes Will Be Different Because Of The Coronavirus 
       I want to talk a little bit about the emotions behind money. I loved what you had to say about being aware of the influences in our life that might affect our habits and our financial voice. I know in my own life, for example, I immediately thought about how my dad was always super, super frugal. You know, he asked for discounts wherever we went. That's a really valuable skill, but as a kid, I just remember feeling so embarrassed. And so now as an adult, I just have zero haggling ability and, you know, probably I'm worse off for it. How do we break those habits? So one of the things I illustrate in the book is one, acknowledging that you see that habit. So that's first. You can't break something that you don't acknowledge and see: what is the habit that I'm seeing in myself? Then, two, exploring where it came from. And so, bravo to you again, Andee for recognizing, 'OK, this is from Dad,' you know. And then three, practicing in a safe environment.  So what I would tell you, is don't worry about the financial haggling for now. You know, if you are not haggling financially, you might be someone that's uncomfortable with asking the waiter for extra cheese— Oh, one hundred percent. I can never send a sandwich back. Okay so that's a baby step. So it's like, sending something back or maybe just asking for something additional like, 'Oh can I also get that,' because what you want to do is you want to practice advocating for yourself. Because it's hard to jump into the financial application if you're not able to advocate for yourself in small, little ways.  That's great advice. I want to talk a little bit about mindful spending. Can you break down the different priorities people should be thinking about for us?  Absolutely. It's: Do I need it? Do I love it? Do I like it? Do I want it? We already know needs: food, shelter, clothing, water. Things you must have to maintain your health and safety. Second, are your loves.  Loves will continue to give you joy six months to a year from now. Likes give you temporary joy, in under six months you might not remember. And wants are fleeting.  So what I want people to do is to lean into the first half of the equation, your needs and your loves. So you need to take care of your health and safety and loves that give you lasting joy, and less money toward likes and wants — not  no  money, but the more money you spend on likes and wants, the less money you have for needs and loves.  You tell this great story in the book and it's about saying no to brunch with your girlfriends for a very specific reason. Can you share that story with us?  Yes, so friends of mine would go to brunch every Sunday and it was maybe, say, 30 to 50 bucks every time. And one day I realized I wanted to go on vacation, but I didn't have any money.  And then when [my friend called] and was like, 'Hey, girl, you want to go to brunch?' I thought to myself, that's where my money is going! And I realized brunch is not a love for me because I don't even remember what we ate last week. I was spending my money on  her  loves.  Now, it's not her fault because she was doing what she was supposed to do, spend her money on her love. But she was convincing me to do so as well. So I stopped going and I almost made it like a drinking game. Every time somebody said "brunch," I put that money in my savings account.  And then when I had enough,  I used it to go on my first solo trip. I wanted to go to Albuquerque because it's the hot air balloon capital of the world and I've never ridden a hot air balloon. And so now I learned that I'm not saying no to brunch, I'm saying yes to Morocco. I'm not saying no to brunch, I'm saying yes to India. I'm saying yes to Monaco. And so I always encourage people to do the same. I want you to use your money to live an actual richer, more joyful life. I want you to make sure you're not using your money towards someone else's idea of love.  So, Tiffany, you came from a household where you were talking about money all the time. But what about people where that where that wasn't the case? How can we get comfortable talking about money?   You're right. I think the average person did not have these conversations at home. So how do you naturally do that? You have to find a safe environment to do so. It might just be a group of your girlfriends where you've said, like, 'I would love you to be my accountability partner and I'm just going to talk about money with you.' And if you don't know anybody in your own physical real life, there are digital folks that you can lean into and virtual people that you can lean into.  I speak freely in front of my friends about money on purpose because I'm always trying to create a safe environment: 'I'm not going to judge; I don't know what's right or wrong for you, I'm just here to present you with as much knowledge as possible so you could choose the right choice for yourself.'  So make sure that when you're looking for these safe spaces, that that's the energy you get.  This piece originally published on March 28, 2021. The podcast version of this episode was produced by  Clare Marie Schneider.   We'd love to hear from you. Leave us a voicemail at 202-216-9823, or email us at  LifeKit@npr.org . For more Life Kit,  subscribe to our newsletter .

So finding a safe environment to do so, and if you don't know anybody in your own physical real life, that there are digital folks that you could lean into and virtual people that you can lean into. I speak freely in front of my friends about money on purpose because I'm always trying to create a safe environment. I'm not going to judge. For me, I don't know what's right or wrong for you. Our relationship with money is emotional, and those feelings are tied to lots of things - your upbringing, your environment, plus, you know, all the money-messaging in the world and the media. Learn to hone your financial voice by first being aware of the money influences in your own life, then take time to examine your financial decision-making. Do you feel mostly good or mostly guilty about your choices? Track your feelings if you're not totally sure where you're at. If you want to change a habit, start small and practice in a safe environment. Maybe enlist a friend to be your accountability partner. Next, be more mindful of your spending by differentiating between your purchases. ALICHE: Do I need it? Do I love it? Do I like it? Do I want it? TAGLE: Remember, a no to a like can and should be reframed as a yes to a love. Your friends and family will understand, and they might just be inspired to do the same. Finally, you can work towards financial wholeness by just talking about it more. Seek out safe spaces with your people or online, and ask the questions you want to ask. Air out your grievances. The more money conversations are out there, the less they're stigmatized, the more empowered we all are. It's just good sense. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) TAGLE: Thanks again to Tiffany Aliche for joining us. Her new book is titled "Get Good With Money." (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) TAGLE: Special thanks to listener Carly Miller (ph) from South Dakota for her budgeting question. For more NPR LIFE KIT, check out our other episodes. If you want more Tiffany, we have an episode with her about how to curb unnecessary spending and another on how to boost your credit. We also have tons of other episodes on parenting, personal finance, health and lots more. You can find those at /lifekit. And if you love LIFE KIT and want more, subscribe to our newsletter at /lifekitnewsletter. Also, we want to hear your tips. Leave us a voicemail at 202-216-9823, or email us at lifekit@npr.org. articles.title: Sirāt is a desert survival story — and one of the year's most gripping films
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Sirāt, a survival film directed by Oliver Laxe, follows a father named Luis, played by Sergi López, and his son Esteban as they journey through the Sahara Desert in search of his missing daughter, Mar. The story begins at a rave in southern Morocco, where a global crisis—likely World War III—has disrupted society. The group of ravers, including actors Stefania Gadda and Jade Oukid, help Luis and Esteban survive the dangerous trek by sharing resources and offering support. The film is visually and sonically immersive, with a score composed by Kangding Ray, and draws comparisons to classic survival films like The Wages of Fear and Sorcerer. Despite its bleak setting, Sirāt emphasizes the enduring power of human kindness and connection in the face of catastrophe, making it both a gripping and emotionally resonant experience.

articles.content:
'Sirāt' is a desert survival story — and one of the year's most gripping films 
         By Justin Chang 
        
           Friday, November 14, 2025 • 11:25 AM EST 
        
        
           Heard on  Fresh Air 
        
      

         The Arabic word  sirāt  means "path" or "way"; in Islamic scripture, it refers to a narrow bridge that connects Paradise and Hell. That makes it a fitting title for the director Oliver Laxe's new movie, which is both exhilarating and devastating.  Sirāt  is a survival story about several unlikely traveling companions making their way through a godforsaken stretch of the Sahara Desert. It carries echoes of countless earlier films, from the arid landscapes of a John Ford Western to the post-apocalyptic setting of  Mad Max . But nothing about  Sirāt  feels derivative or secondhand. It's an astonishing piece of cinema; I haven't had a more gripping experience in a movie theater all year. It begins somewhere in southern Morocco, where hundreds of nomadic European revelers have gathered for a rave. It seems that World War III or something like it has broken out, though the specifics are left vague. Whatever's going on,  Sirāt  initially plays like a party at the end of the world: Imagine a remake of the recent dystopian thriller  Civil War  set at  Burning Man , and you'll have some idea. Laxe, a French-born, Spanish director, sweeps you up in the intense physicality of the dancing and the propulsive beat of the music, composed by the experimental electronic musician Kangding Ray. Wandering around this unruly desert bacchanal is a middle-aged man named Luis, played by the Spanish actor Sergi López. This clearly isn't Luis' scene. Along with his young son Esteban and their dog, Luis is searching for his 20-something daughter, Mar, who vanished months ago, and whom he has reason to suspect is among the ravers.  But she's nowhere to be found, and before long, armed officials show up and, invoking a state of emergency, break up the party. Amid the ensuing chaos, five ravers drive off, bound for another rave further south. Luis and Esteban impulsively drive after them, hoping against hope that they'll find Mar. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In Laxe's previous films, including the 2016 drama  Mimosas , which also chronicled a perilous journey through Morocco, he has worked mainly with non-professional actors. With the exception of López, that's also true here. The director recruited most of the principal cast from raves that he himself attended, and they're all naturals. I especially liked Stefania Gadda as a woman of few words but immense screen presence, and Jade Oukid as a dancer of mesmerizing ability. You feel for these off-the-grid daredevils, and you admire their survival tactics during what will prove to be an exceedingly dangerous trek. While the ravers have an enormous truck and a camper van, Luis and Esteban are in a small van that's ill-equipped for the treacherous terrain. But the ravers, somewhat reluctantly at first, let them tag along. They all share their limited resources, including food, water and gas. And they help each other out, when Luis has trouble fording a small river, or when the truck gets stuck on a steep mountain road.  Sirāt  is a visually and sonically overwhelming experience; it's full of majestic desert vistas and propelled by that thrillingly percussive score. It's also a drama of extraordinary tension and, eventually, shocking tragedy, in which death has a way of striking when you least expect it. I was often reminded of  The Wages of Fear  and  Sorcerer , two classic nail-biters, both adapted from a Georges Arnaud novel about a road trip from hell. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       What separates  Sirāt  from those two films, though, is its lack of cynicism. López is terrific as a father whose child has disappeared and who's understandably wary and mistrustful of the world. But even at his bleakest moments, Luis receives unexpected acts of compassion from his new companions.  At one point, Esteban asks one of the ravers if he misses his family, while traveling on the road, and the raver responds, "I prefer this family." That might sound like something Vin Diesel would say in a  Fast and Furious  movie, and as it happens, Diesel's driving skills might have come in handy here. But Laxe's film is as sincere in its tenderness as it is unrelenting in its ferocity. There's something powerful about the movie's belief that, even as an apocalypse looms, kindness can survive and meaningful relationships can form. Just because the world is pitiless,  Sirāt  suggests, doesn't mean that people have to be.

articles.title: Dear Life Kit: I'm tall. How do I politely ask people to stop bringing it up?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Dear Life Kit, an NPR advice column, addresses three common personal challenges: how to respectfully handle being frequently commented on for one's height, how to communicate intentions about delaying marriage without causing offense, and how to maintain a healthy relationship with a family member who makes hurtful or judgmental remarks. The column is advised by clinical psychologist Adia Gooden and NPR host Brittany Luse, who offer practical, empathetic strategies such as lighthearted deflecting, setting firm boundaries, and distinguishing between valid and harmful opinions. The advice emphasizes emotional self-worth, personal agency, and respectful communication in social and familial contexts.
keyTakeAways: People often comment on height, especially in tall individuals, which can make them feel like a spectacle; a polite, lighthearted response like 'Oh my gosh, you're the first person to tell me that' can deflect the comment while maintaining kindness.
If comments persist, a direct but respectful statement such as 'It's not cool. I'm not comfortable with it. Please stop' can set boundaries without being confrontational.

For couples delaying marriage, it's effective to communicate intentions like being intentional about life choices and avoiding financial debt, using humor or evasiveness to ease pressure from family and friends.

When facing hurtful or judgmental comments from relatives, such as a sister-in-law criticizing personal choices, it's important to recognize that not all opinions are valid, and to set personal boundaries to protect self-worth.

Healthy coping strategies include disengaging from harmful dynamics, clearly defining whose opinions to accept or reject, and involving a partner in managing relationships with difficult family members.
Ultimately, individuals can only control how they respond to criticism — not the behavior of others — and must maintain emotional boundaries to preserve well-being.

articles.content:
Dear Life Kit: I'm tall. How do I politely ask people to stop bringing it up? 
         By Andee Tagle, Sylvie Douglis, Beck Harlan 
        
           Friday, November 14, 2025 • 5:00 AM EST 
        
        
      

        
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Dear Life Kit  is NPR's advice column, where experts answer tricky questions about relationships, social etiquette, work culture and more. Have a question you want to ask Dear Life Kit anonymously?  Share it here.   These questions were answered by Adia Gooden, a clinical psychologist and host of the podcast  Unconditionally Worthy ,  and NPR's Brittany Luse, host of    It's Been a Minute .  The conversation has been edited for length and clarity. Dear Life Kit, I'm a six-foot-tall woman, and both complete strangers and new acquaintances often make comments like, 'Wow, you're tall.' Some people say I should take it as a compliment, but it makes me feel like a spectacle. I don't want to normalize the comments, but I also don't want to embarrass the commenters. How can I respond? —  More than my height   Brittany Luse:  I appreciate the fact that you don't want to embarrass people. I want to offer the idea of maybe not 100% embarrassment or even 60% embarrassment, but a nice, gritty little 15% embarrassment. You can respond with, 'Oh my gosh, you're the first person to tell me that.' Give them a little giggle. Give them the opportunity to laugh with you, but they know you're not playing. And if they don't take the hint the first time, you can be direct. 'Is this catching your attention so much that you have to say something right now?' I think you can give someone one pass with a little joke to let them know you don't like it. And then after that, be really direct. Adia Gooden:  I agree.  If people continue to cross this boundary, be more serious about it. You can say, 'It's not cool. I'm not comfortable with it. Please stop.' If somebody feels a little embarrassed and realizes they shouldn't have said that, that's OK. You're not saying they're an awful person, but you're communicating that what they did is problematic. They should feel a little taste of it so that they stop. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Dear Life Kit, I've been with my boyfriend for seven years. I'm starting to feel pressure from family members and friends to settle down and have a wedding. We're planning to get married, but we want to wait until we are more financially secure. How can I let people know we're not in a hurry to get married without being rude? —  Not in a hurry Gooden:  If people are coming from a loving place, just say, 'We're being really intentional about how we want to start the next chapter of our lives together. Weddings are expensive. We don't want to start our lives together in debt or going into debt.' Luse:   When I was in a similar situation, I would say, 'If you've got tens of thousands of dollars that you want to give me, go right ahead.' Or the other, mildly gentler, response, 'I don't have any updates to share right now, but when I do, you'll be the first to know.' Which is what I say now when people ask me about having children. Gooden:  [If a lighter touch doesn't work,] you can just say, 'Please stop asking us. It's kind of frustrating when you keep asking us about our plans. We will be sure to let you know when we are going in that direction, but until then, please respect our decision-making.' 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Dear Life Kit, My future sister-in-law often says things that are hurtful or judgmental. She once told me, 'I love you, but you're too self-absorbed to own a dog.' And this was over a meal that I brought over for her. I've had pets, raised my younger sister and taken care of my sick mom. I don't think most people would consider me self-absorbed. Her comments bring my fiancé and me down. I've begun avoiding her. How can I cope in a healthy way and still have a relationship with her? —  Feeling frozen? Gooden:  This might be a situation where you need to recognize when someone's comments are not about you. If you know that you're not self-absorbed, then you shouldn't let somebody's comment derail you or override what you know to be true about yourself. So, how do you stay grounded in who you are? You need to discern whose opinion you're going to take and whose opinion you're going to leave. If your wise grandma says, 'Hey, it seems like you've been focusing on yourself a little too much, and I want you to think about this.' That might be different than a comment from a sister-in-law who tends to make judgmental comments. She may be somebody whose opinion you're going to ignore. You may also need to set some boundaries. For example, 'Hey, I feel judged when you give me advice. So I prefer that not to be part of our relationship.' Luse:  At the end of the day, this is your fiancé's sister, and I wonder if he could play a bigger role in managing your relationship with her as a couple. It sounds like maybe he's also feeling the impact of her judgment. I'll share something my therapist said to me once when I was navigating a difficult relationship: 'Have you ever considered that this person may never change? I want you to consider that, and then think about how you want to conduct yourself going forward.' You can't control her. You can only control how and when you interact with her, to a certain degree. The podcast episode was hosted by Andee Tagle and produced by Sylvie Douglis. The digital and visual editor was Beck Harlan. We'd love to hear from you. Leave us a voicemail at 202-216-9823, or email us at LifeKit@npr.org. Listen to Life Kit on  Apple Podcasts  and  Spotify , and sign up for our  newsletter . Follow us on Instagram:  @nprlifekit .

articles.title: Remembering Armero: Colombia's town buried in tragedy
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article recounts the 1985 Armero tragedy in Colombia, where an eruption of the Nevado del Ruiz volcano triggered a deadly mudslide that killed around 25,000 people. Despite prior warnings, residents were unaware of the danger, many of whom were watching a soccer match. Survivors, including veterinarian Fernando Angarita, describe harrowing experiences, with Angarita suffering severe facial injuries. Omayra Sánchez, a 13-year-old girl found trapped in debris, became a national symbol of resilience and is honored with stone plaques at her grave. The article highlights the ongoing search for 583 missing children, with record-keeping chaos making their fates uncertain. The 40th anniversary in 2025 has prompted renewed efforts by survivors and the government to seek answers, including opening child welfare records and launching symbolic boat searches. The event remains a defining moment in Colombian history, emphasizing the need for improved early warning systems and disaster preparedness.
keyTakeAways: The 1985 eruption of Nevado del Ruiz volcano triggered a deadly mudslide that buried the town of Armero, killing approximately 25,000 people and marking it as the deadliest natural disaster in Latin America.
The disaster occurred despite warnings, with residents unaware of danger due to being engrossed in a TV soccer match and delayed evacuation efforts.
Survivors, including veterinarian Fernando Angarita, describe harrowing experiences, with Angarita suffering 16 facial fractures and likening the mudslide to being in a blender.
Omayra Sánchez, a 13-year-old girl found trapped in water, became a symbol of resilience and is now honored in Colombia with hundreds of stone plaques at her grave.
A total of 583 missing children are reported, and their fates remain unclear due to chaotic record-keeping and poor post-disaster coordination.
Colombia has established improved early warning systems and a specialized disaster response agency since 1985 to prevent similar tragedies.
In a symbolic gesture, families launch model boats with photos of missing children into a nearby river, representing a hopeful search for truth and closure.
The Armero tragedy continues to influence Colombian culture and public memory, with survivors maintaining annual visits and a collective mourning process.
